newsitem.title: USA: Cunanan feared he might have AIDS virus -report.
newsitem.headline: Cunanan feared he might have AIDS virus -report.

text.p: Andrew Cunanan, the prime suspect in the murder of designer Gianni Versace, feared he might have contracted the AIDS virus and told a counsellor he would "get" the person who may have transmitted it to him, The San Diego Union-Tribune reported on Saturday.

Two months before he set out on an alleged cross-country murder spree, Cunanan approached Mike Dudley, a volunteer counsellor at an agency for people with AIDS and HIV, the human immunodeficiency virus that causes the disease.

"He started asking me pretty basic questions about HIV transmission," Dudley told the newspaper. "He was mentioning some of the things he had done sexually. I explained the things were sort of in the gray area and (that) he should take greater precautions."
Dudley said Cunanan grew angry during the conversation. He became agitated and he got up and kicked the wall and said: "If I find out who did this to me, I'm gonna get them," Dudley said.
FBI agents have been hunting Cunanan, described as a gregarious, charming male prostitute who lived off wealthy, older gay patrons. He is also wanted in connection with four other murders.
Police say they do not know if fashion designer Versace had any relationship with Cunanan, 27, although reports say the two men had met at least once in San Francisco.
The newspaper said Cunanan never told Dudley whether he had tested positive for HIV.
